However in popular opinion, the first thing that comes to people’s mind is a figure of a strong, sturdy man who fights bad guys or monsters. But how was this stereotype planted into our brain? Just like most of us believe that justice will prevail, in our subconscious we always hope that an undefeatable being who’s on our side would protect us from the danger and injustice in our life. Furthermore, this is the reason why superman-like heroes were born. Throughout the history, human have always created this kind of super-human character in fantasy, to create a figure for them to worship; in 2500BC Sumer we got Gilgamesh, in 1000 BC Israel we got King David, in 600BC Greece we got Heracles, in 200AC China we got Guan Yu, in 500AC England we got King Arthur, in Medieval German we got Siegfried, in 18th century Spain we got Zorro, in 1990s America we got action movie heroes, and now we have marvel super heroes.

Heroism, an ideology that was implanted in mankind since the ancient time, has been a significant factor that influence our thinking, culture, literature, or even our daily life. From Gilgamesh to Superman, we always wish that there’s a hero who can protect us from danger. While in present, someone believe that things need to be done by humans; not gods, not heroes, but humans. As a consequence of this thinking, it’s the rise of anti-heroism. Finally, the bandwagon effect cause by heroism can cause a lot of problems to the society. People who are hypnotized by the idea believe their own fantasy, they can harm others or themselves very easily. In conclusion, a hero is a being with limited power, it has its own justice and it will never betray it, it knows its limit and it will not be arrogant, it knows what it must do and it will achieve it; lastly, a hero can be anybody.

“Humph!” the white man grunted. They had arrived at their destination during his complaint. It was a run-down shed on the brink of the plantation, doubling as the entrance of an ownerless woods. “Clean it up before sunset. Or else the tip of a whip is the only thing you will taste tonight!” The cabin was really shabby; it was nearly impossible to renovate it before dusk, yet Tom didn’t talk back, because he knew it would only bring him more lashes. Fat Eric soon left after he assigned the task, while Tom worked hard for fear of whipping. During the process, Tom couldn’t help but wonder what or who this cottage was for as the building was obviously too small as a storage house; however, the whites would neither live in such garbage heap nor give the slaves a house. Tom didn’t have enough time to reach the answer before sunset, he bore several lashes that night.

Hearing his master’s demand, Tom had no other choice but to accept it. Though he had no knowledge of taking care of others before, he still tried his best to keep good old Irwin safe and sound. Irwin spent most of his days spacing out and Tom came to his cabin every two hours to confirm his well-being and bring him meals. Once he wondered why the old man got such a retirement for average slaves who were usually worked to death, yet he couldn’t get any clues from the deranged senior or his ill-tempered master. Life continued like this for a few months and Tom kind of liked it; not only because he could get some exemption from manual labor, but also reduced the chance of him meeting Eric, which further spared him from possible whipping. However, the peaceful daily routine didn’t last long, tension rose in the South as a white man was hanged for inciting slave rebellion, rumors spread all over the county, the detest and fear in the whites’ eyes grew more and more obvious with each passing day. To make matters worse, several guns went missing from the arsenal while Mr. Jackson, the owner of the plantation, suspected that it was the slaves who stole the firearms and planned to overthrow him.

Research 2 started with a hypothesis: we are either born into or socialized into hating a sound. Seidle first analyzed people’s preference of sound and found that high intensity high frequency sound is not universally hated, for example people showed a significantly higher preference for baby crying than fork scratching on plate. He then compared the sound preference of general USA citizens and Tsimane people from Amazon rainforest, and Tsimane people who live in San Borja and those who remained in the jungle. He found that high intensity sound is much less preferable to the population living in industrialized areas. Another experiment Seidel conducted was to investigate young children’s sound preference, it was surprising to him that children from 3 to 6 years old barely show any sound aversion, and the kids from 7 to 10 showed, even though not as strong as adults’, a relatively more skewed aversion for sounds. Thus Seidel concluded that sound preference is a trait that was learned through socialization, not a biological factor.

Research 4 asked an important question: though having the same answer to a question, do AIs have the same thought process like a human being. The purpose of this research is to mass produce auditory response data through convolutional neural networks of artificial intelligence, since it is cheaper and quicker than hiring human participants. But before that Seidel needs to prove that AI processes audio information like humans, else the data will be pointless. After comparing the cortical firing pattern of the human brain with thousands of layers of tensors in AI models, he finally confirmed that one specific layer responds similarly to the human brain when processing audio. He also found that AIs trained to multi-task function more similarly than those designed to concentrate on a single task. Thus Seidel concluded though still needing more research, some AI models may be plausible for mass producing experiment data with near-perfect accuracy. As a computer science student concentrating in machine learning, I look forward to real world application of this research.

However, even putting the non-STEM courses in consideration, ANTH 100 is a very “broad” course. The content of this course is so broad that there is no other definition for this course other than “study about humans”. Throughout this semester we went from the biological evolution of human species to history of racial theories then jumping back and forth to topics like formation of a society, gender and sex, and a variety of different subjects, branching out to sociology, linguistics, politics, and more fields of studies. This is exactly what I like about this course: it is like reading the encyclopedia for the first time when I was eight, I learned so much interesting new knowledge that I will probably never learn if I did not take ANTH 100. I especially love the videos incorporated into the lectures, the two videos that impressed me the most are the documentary on Mongolian nomads and the breakdown of fictional languages. The documentary shocked me with the existence of modernized nomads herding sheep on motorbikes, and as a hardcore Lord of the Ring who studied Khuzdul in junior high, I genuinely enjoyed learning other fictional languages.

The most visually-stunning artwork was an installation art by Makena Thompson, or Unangax̂ of Egegik by her Inuit name. It was a gillnet woven with multiple materials and several decoration pieces. The art was inspired by Thompson’s Nana (grandma) in Alaska, who worked in commercial salmon fishing that raised two generations of her descendents. In honor of her Nana and the traditional Inuit way of living, fishnet became the core of Thompson’s art. The center piece is the traditional salmon gillnet, but the edge is woven with nylon of different colors, symbolizing the blend of tradition and modern cultures. On the net hung a few pieces of colored glass, which were collected by Thompson from a nearby river in her childhood in Alaska. The two ends of the net were respectively decorated with a cedar cork and a graduation cord. The cork is a heirloom that traced its history back to the 1950s, and the cord is Thompson’s own graduation cord. The linking of the past and present by the fishnet represented the essence of this artwork: “No matter how the world changes, the bond with my root always perseveres”.

I talked to my friend Arnob on our way from Stewart center to Corec after class. Our conversation was mainly about workout (as we’re heading to the gym), especially on the workout menu and his comment on using testosterone. We’re walking and talking so we don’t always face each other, but I always look into his eyes when I’m making a point. Recently Arnob started to use testosterone and tried to convince me to join him. I joked around and tried to divert the topic as long as possible, I didn’t want to straight up reject him and hurt his feelings. I can relate to him because he was also fat like me, it took him 4 years in the gym to be buffed as he is today. He got into a bottleneck recently as he could not get any stronger without medication, and testosterone was his way out. However, in the end he pushed too hard and I had to tell him with a straight face, I don’t want to use any drug, whether it is steroids or testosterone. He backed down for now but I’m pretty sure he will pick this up some other day, that is just who he is.

The picture on the bottom left is a Taiwanese teenager making a mockery out of the president during an interview. His reaction is the portrayal of how most young Taiwaneses feel about this country nowadays: absurd. The ruling party only cares about elections, the birth rate is dropping, the economy is crumbling, the mafias are thriving, and these are just the tip of the iceberg. It is so desperate and so beyond saving that it makes us want to laugh, as it is the only thing we can do in this farcical society. The political and historical background of Taiwan is one of the major reasons why I choose to study abroad. The image on the top right is my middle school classroom, and it is taken at 8 p.m. Taiwan, like the rest of other east asian countries, is an examination hell. Private schools forced students as young as middle schoolers to stay at school and study until 10 p.m.; while public schools don’t have such rules, students generally go to cram schools afterwards. This type of cramming education is another major factor that goaded me to leave Taiwan.

Personally, I believe McIntosh’s list is a generalized rather than accurate roster that determines who has special access and who gets marginalized at Purdue, there are too many loopholes that can be exploited and need specification. For example, item 39 states “If you have more than fifty books in your household” as a privilege. Is it implying “the financial capability to afford fifty books” a privilege or “raised in an intellectual household” a privilege? What if one has one hundred e-books in their ipad instead of fifty hardcopies? What if the family regularly visits the library but doesn’t keep books in the household? There are simply too many interpretations to be made, so I don’t consider this list accurate. Also, I feel like some items need to be subtracted or modified for they don’t fit into Purdue’s current condition. For example, item 5 states “If you rely, or have relied, primarily on public transportation” a disadvantage. This is especially not true, for most of us travel by our own two feet, does this make us more privileged than those who take buses? Not to mention CityBus is free no more! Instead the list should make “primarily travel by personal motorized vehicle” a privilege, not “rely primarily on public transportation” a marginalization.

In Episode One - The Difference Between Us, the documentary focuses on unraveling common myths about race and reinterprets the concept with modern standards: It debunks the belief of races as biological categories but reaffirms races as cultural identification. The video states the idea of biological race was fabricated solely for the purpose of proving one race is better than the other, it is fake science that forces lines between dots to reach a predetermined conclusion. With modern genetic studies we know that the variation of DNA sequence between homo sapiens is extremely small compared to other intraspecies differences, the genetic variation of two fruit flies might be as different as a human to a chimpanzee. Thus, most of us are practically genetically alike, it is only that one in a million gene strand that contribute to our appearance is different, then the concept of race is created because we are most used to identify by physical appearance. In fact, a black man can be more genetically similar to a white man than another black man, and vice versa.

Whether it was school or family education, I was always taught to be nice to everyone, especially to the elderly and the disabled. My parents told me that generosity is a virtue, and the world will be a better place if everyone is willing to lend a helping hand. The story took place when I was a sixth grader, on my way to a convenience store to buy dinner. I saw a granny sitting on the stairs in front of the store, looking around and maybe in need of help. As soon as we met eyes, she approached me. With her shaky voice she told me she lost her wallet and needed 200 dollars to call a taxi back home, she said everyone but me brushed her off and begged me to help her. I was very hesitant, 200 dollars was all I was given, if I gave it all to her, I would need to starve till tomorrow when my parents got home. In the end, I followed my conscience and gave her the money. Now here comes the twist, my dad came home early that night and decided to bring me to a midnight diner as a reward for my kindness. However, as we passed by that same convenience store, I saw that granny again. She was still sitting on the staircase, but this time with a bottle of soju in her left hand and a lighted cigarette in another. I was shocked and confused, I didn’t understand why she didn’t make her way back home, I didn’t grasp the truth behind this “poor helpless old woman” hoax until much later. It turns out she’s a local hobo who regularly pesters bypassers for booze and smokes. I just happened to bump into her and was an easy target.

The most straightforward factor that contributed to my concern is the Absurdistan, or the double speaking I encounter in my everyday life. As you must also know as a denizen of Novotroitsk, the metallurgy industry has always been the pride and backbone of this town; and as the editor of the only newspaper in this town, I assume you also heard of the recent factory layoff that suspended dozens of workers indefinitely. The official statement from the manager claimed that this is merely a “temporal adjustment of personnel”, yet me and my fellow workers all knew this suspension was due to the shortage of chemical solution. The shipment of hydrochloric acid and fluorspar, the critical chemical used in the process of extraction and smelting, had been reducing months before the layoff. And this decrease in shipment, I speculated, is due to the new chemical company we formed a new partnership with a few years ago. I still remember the day when the manager announced the new contract  signed with InfraLeuna, a Western Germany corporation whose subsidiary specializes in the production of industrial chemicals. At the time when all western enterprises were labeled as evil capitalist, ruthless imperialist, and oppressors of the working class; this statement was quite shocking for all the factory workers. However, the manager soon released a new statement that claimed that InfraLeuna “realized their wrongdoing in assisting capitalist oppression” and “turned to the Union in hope of supporting the great communist work”. If I recall correctly, the statement was even published on Novotroitsk News! As a result, we accepted this new arrangement without much comment until last week, the very day we were put on an indefinite suspension.

At the beginning of the episode, a reporter greets Bart out of politeness, while Bart replies with a stereotypical redneck response “Who the hell are you?”.  At the same time Bart is chewing a barley straw, which is another stereotype for American southerners. The exaggeration of uneducated Americans is shown here, for even the kids are acting like a mid-aged redneck. When Mr. Burns makes his debut on the TV show to announce his entrance of the election, everyone scoffs at him and wishes him to get lost. However, as Burns hired an actor portraying Charles Darwin who claims the three-eyed fish is an evolutionary leap instead of a hideous genetic mutation, a bunch of people immediately change their opinion on Burns, some even call him new blood for American politics. The uneducated Americans are easily manipulated by the information they receive, yet they don’t have the ability to tell right from wrong. The parody of Charles Darwin and the exaggeration of mass ignorance are displayed in this scene, the media has become a new tool for businessmen and politicians to control people.

You wake up on a pile of golden flowers, you look around but no one is around, as you investigate the area you remember you fell down Mount Ebott, a place forbidden by the adults, also the habitat the monsters dwell. Welcome to the world of Undertale, here you play as a child to explore the underground and try to find a way back to the surface. During your adventure you will meet several monsters, but instead of savage monsters the adults told you, they are intelligent beings with emotion and soul. When you encounter a monster, you can choose to fight and kill it or try to communicate and make peace with it. If you spare the monsters and explore the underground peacefully, you will find that every character in the game has a story behind it, and all of their stories connect to each other to create the massive plot of Undertale.

While Undertale is, at the end of the day, a game steeped in fiction, the effects of its music on a player’s overall experience is very much grounded in reality. Look no further than the first encounter in the game, where we meet our titular antagonist, Flowey the flower. Flowey, as Aaron mentioned before, is indeed the final boss of the game, but from his initial charming and inviting demeanor, a player would be oblivious as to his ulterior motives. Flowey’s theme, titled, “Your Best Friend”, mirrors his innocent appearance with a cute, simplistic melody in the key of Ab major, lulling the player into a false sense of security. When Flowey does decide to show his true colors in the form of Omega Flowey near the end game, we hear this leitmotif once again, distorted, bizarre, and with an accelerated tempo, which induces a sense of fear and hatred in the player.

At the end of the route, Flowey will tell you a way to reach the true pacifist route and restart the game before the final boss fight. You will fight the true form of Flowey, which is Asgore’s deceased son Asriel. This time you will save this last soul you didn’t save in the last run and reach the true happy ending. In the genocide route you choose to deal things with violence instead of mercy. To achieve this run you need to kill every monsters in the game, and as you continued to slay more and more monsters just because you want get the genocide ending, you will find yourself the true final boss and the monsters are the heroes who try to defeat you. When you finally kill everything that moves in the game, the soul of the first human who fell underground appears, he is the one and only friend of Asriel, also the narrator that guides you throughout the game. He will kill the protagonist and crash the game, force you to play this game over and over again, never leave him alone.

As influential as movies can be, the author can only recall one that envisions a world where humans live in harmony with nature—Black Panther. The nation of Wakanda surprisingly maintains its environment despite being, in canon, the most technologically-advanced country in the world. This is in large part because Wakanda lacks suburbs which, as proven in the United States, does more harm to the environment than urban territories. The very capital city of Birnin Zana is assimilated with nature, making it more sustainable and environmentally beneficial than any other in real life. Compounded with the fact that studies have shown that suburban lifestyle isn’t especially good for humans, the methodology that went into creating Wakanda looks more and more appealing. Wakandans chose to tell a story that differs from not only the titular antagonist Killmonger but also from many films of today, and the author champions this idea. Instead of a resigned undercurrent, the author wants movies of today to discuss climate change with an opportunistic viewpoint, one that would benefit not only the environment, but the general public as well. The author ends the essay with her own optimistic take on an ecologically-orientated story, rallying the audience into becoming one with nature and reconstructing a new narrative.

The extreme weather occurring around the globe in recent years is the environmental issue being discussed in Weathering with You. Throughout the story, many people asked for Hina’s help to hope for good weather; whether it is important events such as weddings or petty wishes like “want to walk under the sun”,  Hina realized them all. Yet the price of the miracles was not only high but also cruel: Hina's special power came from her identity as a human offering to the god of weather, and every time she prayed for good weather her body became more and more transparent. Also the storms Hina cleared didn’t disappear, they were only delayed. As Hina stopped praying in fear of the transformation, all the bad weather struck back all at once. Rain flooded Tokyo, the city was on the verge of destruction. Finally, Hina could not bear to watch others suffer, she prayed one last time and disappeared from this world. As she fully transformed into a live offering, the rain stopped pouring and the wind halted howling, the world was saved by the sacrifice of a 16-year-old girl.

To the US, this principle is not the most favorable but rather an acceptable one. America would never be happy to be at the giving end instead of the receiving end of economic merit, yet to reduce carbon emission globally, it is a necessary sacrifice. The United States will have to restart the various environmental policies previously canceled by the Trump Administration and fulfill the 26% reduction promise made in the Paris Agreement. In addition, the US needs to foster advanced technology industries in South America to shift their economic focus from heavy industry and exhaustive forestry. To prevent raising the cost of living and causing popular discontent, the US might need to cut short other budget expenses, such as national defense. To other developed countries, their conditions are very much the same to the states, just on a smaller scale. These nations need to continue or renew their carbon emission policy while aiding their neighboring developing nations like the US to South America, with the premise that these altercations won’t significantly increase the cost of living. The government and citizens of developed countries need to strike a balance between these conditions, which may involve decreasing luxury and other unnecessary expenses.

To China, it should cease its current checkbook diplomacy and focus on solving its internal issues. China is the world’s largest emitter of carbon dioxide, it needs to cut short its carbon emission by transitioning from fossil fuel to renewable energy. China is a country that suffers severe wealth inequality, most capital is in the possession of government officials and the merchants bonded with them. Besides implicit corruption, a significant amount of money is spent on China’s ally nations to politically compete with NATO nations instead of helping the poor Chinese citizens. These issues need to be resolved before China can efficiently cut down carbon emission while overcoming the financial instability brought by rapid economic growth. To India, the situation is almost identical to China. India’s wealth inequality has its convoluted roots in the caste system, corruption, religion, and external conflict. It is India’s responsibility to solve or at least mitigate its social and economic conundrums in order to allocate resources for emission reduction movements.

Cost wise, while nuclear is not cheapest on the list yet it is definitely more affordable than fossil fuels, both coal and gas. As renewable energies are considerably cheaper than nuclear energy, its massive landuse and unreliability is a great concern. It takes ten times more land to establish an effective solar and wind power plant, the land that can be utilized far more economically efficiently. Speaking of efficiency, the conversion of either solar wind or geothermal energy into electricity hasn’t ever reached 50% since its invention. Compared to the 90% energy factor of nuclear energy, renewable energies alone won’t be able to provide electricity on a national, or even a regional scale. In addition to inefficiency, unlike nuclear and fossil fuels, renewables are often bound to the environment, solar power needs a sunny climate, Hydroelectricity requires waterfalls, … etc, in contrast to the reliable nuclear power plants that can produce electricity 24/7, renewable energies are simply not good enough.

The assertion that we learn our most valuable lessons from struggling with our limitations rather than from enjoying our successes is a compelling one. While successes can certainly provide joy and satisfaction, it is often the challenges and difficulties that teach us the most profound and enduring lessons. I largely agree with this claim, though it is also important to recognize that successes can play a crucial role in reinforcing and validating the lessons learned through struggle. Struggling with limitations often forces individuals to confront their weaknesses, rethink their strategies, and develop resilience. For instance, Thomas Edison’s numerous failures in inventing the light bulb illustrate how struggles can lead to significant learning and eventual success. Edison famously stated that he had not failed but had found 10,000 ways that did not work. His persistence and problem-solving through repeated failures ultimately led to a groundbreaking invention that transformed modern life. This example underscores how grappling with limitations can be a powerful teacher, fostering persistence, creativity, and critical thinking.

Similarly, athletes frequently experience growth through overcoming setbacks. Consider the story of Michael Jordan, who was famously cut from his high school basketball team. This early failure motivated him to work harder and refine his skills, ultimately leading to a highly successful career in professional basketball. Jordan’s struggle with rejection and limitation taught him valuable lessons about perseverance and self-improvement that were instrumental in his later achievements. His experiences demonstrate that struggles often provide the impetus for personal development and future success. On the other hand, successes can also offer important lessons and affirmations of one’s abilities. Achieving a goal can boost confidence, validate one’s efforts, and provide motivation for future endeavors. For example, a student who successfully completes a challenging academic project may gain confidence in their problem-solving abilities and become more motivated to tackle future challenges. Successes can also serve as milestones that reinforce the effectiveness of strategies and hard work, offering valuable feedback and encouragement.

However, while successes provide positive reinforcement, they often do not compel the same level of self-reflection and growth as struggles do. Successes can sometimes lead to complacency, where individuals rest on their laurels rather than seeking continuous improvement. In contrast, overcoming limitations often requires a deeper level of introspection and adaptation. The process of addressing and overcoming difficulties can lead to more profound personal growth and a better understanding of one’s capabilities and potential. Moreover, challenges and limitations frequently teach individuals about the importance of resilience and the value of effort. For example, entrepreneurs who navigate financial difficulties or business failures often emerge with a greater understanding of risk management, strategic planning, and adaptability. These lessons are frequently more impactful and enduring than those learned from straightforward successes, which may not always require as much effort or introspection.

It is pure irony that the Europeans, who profess to believe in the dignity of human beings, are the initiators, the perpetrators, and the sole beneficiaries of the most notorious human trafficking industry in the annals of mankind. Throughout the three hundred years history of the transatlantic slave trade, over 12.5 million Africans were snatched from their home and shipped to the plantations in the Americas, where they were dehumanized, commodified, bred like livestocks, then thrown away like rubbish. Although slavery was officially banned in the 19th century, it took one more century for people to fully recognize the true horror of the atrocities committed in the past. What could possibly rationalize this systematic deprivation of human rights? How did the Europeans of the early modern era sell millions of men as goods without remorse or guilt? Simply yet astonishingly, the Europeans justified the Atlantic slave trade with merely two reasons: money and moral.

The Reformation, one of the most significant events in Christian history, was initiated by one troubled man. Martin Luther was an anxious Christian who suffered from existential crisis due to the fear of failing God’s expectation of him. Throughout the first half of his life, Luther searched for an answer, a solution that would free him from the persistent fears of damnation. During his study of penance at Wittenberg, Luther reached enlightenment. Luther came to his own realization that “eternal salvation came not from performing the religious good works of penance, but from faith, which was a gift from God”, he no longer need to worry about whether he did enough to be worthy of salvation, he just need to believe in God, and God would make the righteous judgment. From this moment of revelation, Luther would stray more and more from the path of Catholicism and eventually form his new version of Christianity. However, it was an extensive process of thought transformation that lasted for more than twenty years. From a confused believer to a stout opposer of papacy, Martin Luther underwent several drastic events that shift his mindset from time to time.

We will utilize the web-scraped data we gathered up until now and continue to web-scrape the websites the mentors provide in the future. We will use the manually labeled well structured data in csv format as answer sheets for testing the accuracy for our large language models, and use the unfiltered web-scraped raw text data as the training data, which we will further divide into training, validation, and testing sets.  Also we will experiment with the size and format of raw text data, to see what batch size and file format produce the best desired output. Due to the immense time, cost, and data requirement needed to train a large language model from zero, we decided to adopt the pre-trained models from online sharing platforms and finetune the model to specifically extract manufacturing speaks from text data. The focus of this semester is Ollama, which we already experimented with several model families on. In the first sprint of the next semester we will also look into Hugging Face, another AI sharing platform, and explore more models we can possibly employ.

World War I and the Napoleonic Wars, two of the most important modern wars, each left its own bloody yet significant marks on the annals of European history. Both wars were fueled by fervent nationalism, caused countless casualties, introduced advanced warfare, and led to substantial shifts in power and ideology not limited to the Europe continent but also the colonies around the globe. However, though the two wars hold many commonalities, they still possess several differences, especially in the experiences of frontline soldiers. The technological breakthrough in the 100 years between the two eras fundamentally altered the definition of war. The amount of casualties drastically increased in WWI, and the post-traumatic stress disorder was of much greater scale compared to the Napoleonic Wars. Overall, the life of a World War I soldier is more stagnant, unpredictable, and hopeless than a Napoleonic soldier due to the advanced weaponry, trench warfare, and the mass mobilization made possible in the 20th century.

And as for why InfraLeuna cut back our supply, it was hard to not relate to the horrible accident that took place three years ago. Chernobyl not only left a huge scar on the direct victim of the incident, it also undermined the trust we had in the government. My sister Ludmila and her family living in Pripyat bore the brunt of that terrible disaster. I had a phone call with Ludmila the night before the explosion, we talked about the upcoming birthday of my precious little niece Sasha and my plan to visit them in May. That was the last time I heard from them in weeks. I didn’t even know about the disaster three days after it happened, and I knew something was off when Вре́мя claimed that the power plant was under control yet I could not contact my sister. It turned out my sister’s family was emergency evacuated out of the city in the midnight of April 27th, then in the following month they along with other residents of Pripyat were transported place to place, from decontamination sites to refugee camps, rural villages to unfamiliar towns; it took them a month to finally settle in Kyiv and inform me that they were tired but unharmed.

Being “relieved” from my work recently, I finally had the opportunity to experience the infamous grocery queues. It was an awfully dull and wasteful occurrence, I waited from daybreak for six hours in the long and winding line, just to be disappointed by the farcical “goods” at the end of it. The shops didn’t even have the 100th of what they showed on TV: there was no meat, no vegetables, no milk, no fruit; there was nothing other than bread as hard as rock. Most importantly, they have no toilet paper. Not even a single sheet! Me and my family had to resort to rags made from old clothes and past newspapers! It is such a woeful situation, that both the metal we export and the groceries we import are in deplorable scarcity. I know it is a hard time for everybody, but things could be better. I wish my letter can raise the government’s awareness of what the people really need, instead of deluding themselves with propaganda that is too good to be true.

The Gilded Age, an era marked as the pinnacle of “the American dream”, is one of the most luxurious years in American history. Under rapid economic growth and industrial expansion, mass urbanization took place and cities flourished, quality of life soared, everything seemed so glamorous and wonderful. However, under the canvas of the illustrious image, social issues bred; widespread corruption, outright racism, and rising unemployment slowly infested the society as people reveled in clubs and ballrooms. The Great Sheedy Trial, a murder case that occurred in Lincoln, Nebraska, demonstrated the typical racism that pervaded the Gilded Age. By examining the case of the black suspect Monday McFarland, the racial oppression concealed for ages is finally brought to the light.

Before diving into the invention, we had to understand what exoskeleton is. Exoskeleton is also known as powered suit, it is a wearable mobile machine that is powered by a system of electric motors, pneumatics, levers, hydraulics, and a combination of technologies that allow for limb movement with increased strength and endurance; or in short a robot suit that can make you super strong.  Powered suit has implications in all walks of life, for example: it can be used for medical purposes, like utilizing exoskeleton as prosthetics for disabled or elderly. "Step Rehabilitation Robots" have helped individuals who lost the use of their legs from stroke, spinal cord injury or during aging by enabling system-assisted walking. Exoskeleton can also be used for military purposes, which advance soldiers’ physical affinity or prevent suffering from possible injuries. For example, the Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit (TALOS) had been employed in US army to increase mobility and reduce fatigue of Special Forces operators.

The Guardian XO exoskeleton – the world’s first commercially-available full-body, battery-powered industrial wearable robot that delivers superhuman strength and endurance. In recent years exoskeletons have been increasingly invested into industry, with the goal of reducing worker injury and reducing errors due to fatigue, while The Guardian marks a milestone of the industry. To be distinguished from other brands, The Guardian is able to lift and manipulate up to 90 kg while virtually eliminating any physical strain, and also boasts as much as six hours of battery life. Historically, highly physical jobs have been relegated to larger and stronger people. If more and more companies adopt versatile exoskeletons, it means that there will no longer be physical barriers to entry for these roles. In essence, it will allow various highly-physical industries to maintain a more diverse talent pool.

The most outright and consequential difference between WWI and the Napoleonic Wars is the weapons deployed. Napoleonic foot soldiers were generally equipped with smoothbore flintlock muskets having a firing rate of 2 ~ 3 rounds per minute, while frontline troops in WWI were armed with bolt action rifles which are not only capable of firing 12~20 rounds per minute but also with a far higher precision. The artillery batteries in Napoleonic era used cannons whose destructive ability solely relied on the mass and momentum of the projectiles, in comparison WWI gunnery crews utilized howitzers and mortars that fired explosive shells whose shockwave and shrapnels further enhanced the lethality. Aside from an upgrade from preexisting weaponries, WWI also introduced new devices of destruction unprecedented in human history. Rapid-firing machine guns empowered a handful of soldiers to outgun their enemies even with a lopsided number ratio, chemical weapons could smother enemies en masse with just a twist of valve on the gas canister.

With a brief examination of the juries, the judges decided that McFarland’s testimony would be sufficient evidence to corroborate their guiltiness. However, the attorneys argued that several pieces of evidence were fabricated, for a witness Novia Snell was proven forced to file fake information against the two defendants. In addition, the most critical piece of evidence, Monday McFarland’s confession, was obtained through the means of torture and extortion. As fruit of the poisonous tree can not be eaten, evidence gained with illegal methods can not be considered valid either. As the trial continued, the prosecutors intended to use McFarland as a tool against Mary Sheedy by emphasizing McFarland’s confession, however, their proposal ended with failure for McFarland claimed he had confessed falsely in fear of death threat. The manner the juries and the police demonstrated throughout the whole case showed how the judicial system is unfair to black suspects: a black man can be captured without warranty, forced confession with torture, and convicted without sufficient evidence.

The log-and-dirt fortification seemed to devour any and all incoming damage, and the tally of casualties on both sides still stood at an emphatic zero—a number that was sure to change very soon.  “Sharp, isn’t he, Chitto?” muttered a fellow Lower Creek beside me, gesturing at the figure that was leading our motley band of warriors. “Sharp as a knife, he is.” His voice oozed with resentment that had been building even before the Whites had sought our assistance. “When’s he gonna try ‘nother one of his brilliant plans, eh?”

I couldn’t help but scoff at the general’s lofty statement. The Red Sticks were nothing if not tenacious, and it boggles the mind to think that someone would still underestimate them. I have hunted enough wild beasts to know that a cornered fox is often more dangerous than the hungriest wolf. Scouts had reported around a thousand Red Stick warriors defending the secluded village of Tohopeka, each of whom ready to fight to their last gasp of air. In one of our prior skirmishes, I was dealt a savage blow by one of their notorious scarlet war clubs, and I was not eager to endure that excruciating pain once again. My musings of the past were cut short by distant gunshots and screams, emanating from the village. Coffee had successfully infiltrated Tohopeka.  “That’s our cue, gentlemen,” the general said with a giddy, almost child-like grin, “let the battle truly begin. 39th Infantry, charge!” The command had barely left his lips before the battalion began to surge forward, knives and daggers protruding from all angles like the quills of a porcupine.

The veterinarian showed me from simple treats such as calming down the animals, removing parasites, packaging medicine, to some surgical techniques like amputation, electro-coagulation, and surgical suturing. Once, they even brought me to the patients’ home to practice euthanasia on an old collie. I watched the veterinarian sternly and carefully injected three syringes into the collie’s forelimb, with the collie’s family sobbing, and me gently stroking its back. This internship not only enriched me intellectually but also spiritually. Watching the vets being bitten and scratched while curing the animals, I learned from their great patience and willingness of self-sacrifice. Through the practice of euthanasia, I understood the duty of a veterinarian is beyond keeping our best friends healthy and happy, aiming for the complete dignity of animals’ lives that we owe. After this internship, my chest is swollen with respect for veterinarians, and I am more certain than ever that I want to follow their paths.

In the digital era, cybersecurity has become a paramount concern for individuals and organizations alike. The recent surge in cyber attacks highlights the vulnerability of digital infrastructure and the need for robust security measures. Cybersecurity strategies now prioritize not only the protection of sensitive information but also the resilience of systems to ensure continuity in the face of threats. Advances in encryption technology and the development of more sophisticated firewalls have been critical in defending against hackers. However, the human element remains the weakest link, with social engineering attacks exploiting human psychology rather than technical flaws. Education and awareness programs have thus become essential components of comprehensive cybersecurity plans, aiming to equip people with the knowledge to recognize and resist phishing attempts and other deceptive practices.

In the 1980s, neuroscientists studying the brain processes underlying our sense of consciousness compared subjects’ judgments regarding their subjective will to move (W) and actual movement (M) with objective electroencephalographic activity called readiness potential, or RP. As expected, W preceded M: subjects consciously perceived the intention to move as preceding a conscious experience of actually moving. This might seem to suggest an appropriate correspondence between the sequence of subjective experiences and the sequence of the underlying events in the brain. But researchers actually found a surprising temporal relation between subjective experience and objectively measured neural events: in direct contradiction of the classical conception of free will, neural preparation to move (RP) preceded conscious awareness of the intention to move (W) by hundreds of milliseconds.

Historians frequently employ probate inventories — lists of possessions compiled after a person’s death — to estimate standard of living. Because these inventories were taken by amateur assessors according to unwritten rules, they are sometimes unreliable. One way to check their accuracy is to compare them to archaeological records. A study of records from the state of Delaware in the eighteenth century found that while very few inventories listed earthenware, every excavation contained earthenware. Earthenware may have gone unlisted simply because it was inexpensive. But if it was so commonplace, why was it listed more often for wealthy households? Perhaps the more earthenware people had, the more likely appraisers were to note it. A few bowls could easily be absorbed into another category, but a roomful of earthenware could not.

You may have heard that tomatoes and processed tomato products like tomato sauce and canned tomatoes protect against some types of cancer. The cancer-preventing properties of tomato products have been attributed to lycopene. It is a bright red pigment found in tomatoes and other red fruits and is the cause of their red color. Unlike other fruits and vegetables, where nutritional content such as vitamin C is diminished upon cooking, processing of tomatoes increases the concentration of lycopene. Lycopene in tomato paste is four times more than in fresh tomatoes. This is because lycopene is insoluble in water and is tightly bound to vegetable fiber. Thus, processed tomato products such as pasteurized tomato juice, so up, sauce, and ketchup contain the highest concentrations of lycopene. Cooking and crushing tomatoes as in the canning process and serving in oil-rich dishes such as spaghetti sauce or pizza greatly increase assimilation from the digestive tract into the bloodstream. Lycopene is a fat-soluble substance, so the oil is said to help absorption to a great extent.

The grey wolf also known as the timber wolf or wolf is a mammal of the order Carnivore. Genetic studies indicate the grey wolf shares a common ancestry with the domestic dog and might be its ancestor. Many other grey wolf subspecies have been identified however the actual number of subspecies is still open to discussion. Though once abundant over much of North America and areas of Europe and Asia, the grey wolf inhabits a very small portion of its former range because of the widespread destruction of its habitat. Gray wolves are highly adaptable and have thrived in forests, deserts, mountains, tundra and grasslands. They function as social predators and hunt in packs organized according to strict social hierarchies. It was originally believed that this comparatively high level of social organization was related to hunting success, and while this still may be true to a certain extent, emerging theories suggest that the pack has less to do with hunting and more to do with reproductive success.

Russian President Putin and Chinese leader Xi oversaw the launch of a pipeline from Russia to China. This act strengthens the political and economic relations between China and Russia. In earlier years, Russia suffered economic sanctions from the West after annexing Crimea, and its economy suffered as a result. This pipeline opens up a new market for one of Russia’s top exports -- natural gas. This pipeline runs from the Chayandinskoye and Kovykta fields in eastern Siberia, through Heilongjiang and Jilin to Liaoning. The gas is produced by the Russian state-owned company Gazprom, which is a major source of income for the Russian government. The pipeline is projected to ship 38 billion cubic meters of natural gas per year by the year 2025, which would make China the second-largest consumer of Russian gas after Germany at 58.5 billion cubic meters in 2019. This is also a response to American efforts at reducing the reliance on Russia natural gas in Western Europe by shipping liquified natural gas to these countries.

Pirates are often depicted  as infamous outlaws that roam and plunder the sea; however, many were actually mercenaries working for one nation to attack the ships of another. Privateers, originally called buccaneers, were a group of men abandoned by  society, like runaway African slaves, escaped criminals, or even defectors. These people formed a large number of buccaneering communities on the islands of Central America, and tried to make a living by fishing, gathering, and trading. The nomads soon drew the attention of European countries such as Spain and Portugal, who  tried to force the buccaneers off their promised land by cutting off  their food supplies; yet this movement backfired as the communities had no choice but to start committing  sea robbery in order to stay alive. Piracy eventually ran wild as the buccaneers found profit in it, but mere pirates didn’t stand a chance against the mighty navy of Spain, and it was the time that Britain got involved in the region. The English government hired the buccaneers as mercenaries to ransack Spanish cargo ships; and in exchange for their labor, the British offered them the support of legal authority, which were permission and equipment.

I met my brother on my sister’s wedding day in 2021, the first time I met her too. The next time I saw him was this summer as we watched his cold body get lowered precariously into the ground on a steep hillside in Oklahoma. It was the kind of hot day where nothing you do will stop you from sweating. As a group of men, including another brother of mine, struggled with his casket over the recently dug hole, I heard his wife morbidly joke, “haven’t you all done this before?”. I stood next to my late brother’s estranged oldest daughter, my technical niece I am trying to know, and my sister being comforted by her husband. The anger was palpable from his daughter he left behind and the sorrow overflowing from our sister – I was somewhere in between. Angry and terribly sad that I hardly knew him. It didn’t need to be this way yet this is what the fertility world carefully created and designed. I was not supposed to know him or any of them. I was not supposed to want to.

The cottonwoods and locusts then take the lead, bright yellow and fluttery orange waving, then dancing down on the omnipresent wind. The cottonwoods stayed on schedule, but the locust trees waited, joining the others in a late turn and shed. Come Halloween, the first flush of color developed on the Bradford pears, a few carefully nursed maples, the red oaks, and the locusts. By this past week, the entire city boasted crimsons and purple-red, dark brown to pale brown to beautiful green-yellow that glowed in the sun. Magnolias and a few others remained green, adding a contrast that pleased the eye. The wind added sound, whispering and hissing among the dying leaves, then taking a few as dance partners, twirling and skating them down to the ground. Passing cars tossed them back into the air to settle once more. The temperature proclaimed late summer, but the eyes declared autumn, as did the early evenings and longer nights. Slanted southern light turned red and orange leaves into glowing jewels against a mild blue sky. Hints of wood smoke, more from smokers than fireplaces, teased of the turning of the year. Winter will come soon, and true cold, and perhaps cold rain that will drag the last color off the trees.

Pesto alla genovese is one of those ingredients that is much better when made at home, even if you use a blender instead of a mortar and pestle. There are two reasons for this. First, almost all store-bought pesto contains incorrect ingredients: pine nuts are replaced with cashews, extra virgin olive oil with sunflower or canola oil, Parmigiano Reggiano with other cheeses, and sometimes even some of the basil is substituted with spinach or parsley. Second, the flavor of homemade pesto is fresher, brighter, and more complex. And if you have a blender, it’s not a lot of work. The most time-consuming part is stripping the basil leaves from the stems. Making homemade lasagna is a lot of work, especially if you prepare fresh pasta dough, but it’s absolutely worth it. Most people are familiar with lasagne alla bolognese, but one of my favorites is lasagne alla genovese. Both dishes feature the most iconic recipe from their respective hometowns: ragù alla bolognese from Bologna, and pesto alla genovese from Genoa. In the Genovese version, the pesto is mixed with béchamel, and the lasagna is layered with grilled zucchini or green beans, sometimes with the addition of boiled potatoes.

Was it the start of blogging? Technically, no. People were hand-coding HTML diaries to the soundtrack of dial-up long before 2001. But Valdrighi did something quietly important: he helped democratise it for anyone with a cheap shared host and a bit of curiosity. With b2/cafelog, you did not need to wrestle with raw HTML every time you wanted to post. You logged in, wrote, clicked publish. Was it the start of “posting”? In a small way, yes. Before infinite scroll and algorithmic feeds, there was the simple, chronological rhythm of the cafelog. It was one of the early ancestors of the modern “feed”, but with fewer distractions and a lot more intention. But the real spark was something bigger. Michel Valdrighi did not just create a way to write; he helped show how powerful open code can be in the real world. By choosing the GPL license, he showed that code does not have to be guarded to matter. Shared code can travel farther and live longer.

“Cafelog” didn’t sound like enterprise software; it sounded like a digital notebook kept by someone in a café, sipping espresso and sending thoughts into the ether. It was not built for dashboards, pipelines, or approval workflows. It was built for expression. For publishing. For having a place where your words could live. For a slice of the early web, it felt small, elegant, and cool, and it quietly became the blogging tool of choice for many early adopters. But then Michel did the thing every developer sometimes has to do, and every user quietly worries about: he stepped away. Around 2002, the updates slowed and then stopped. Emails piled up. Life moved on, and the creator went quiet for a while. In a world of closed, proprietary software, that is often where the story ends. If the people with access to the source code leave, the product freezes in time and eventually fades away.

There are already many things that could be improved by a declining birth rate. Teacher-student ratios would improve. Homeless people would be better able to find safe places to live. Unemployed people would be better able to find jobs. Per capita food production would increase. Per-capita access to fresh water would increase. Carbon emissions would decrease. Now that I’m in my 20s, I’m starting to see adulthood for what it actually is - not the freedom and independence we were taught to expect, but a system that feels like it’s already claimed huge pieces of our lives before we even start living them. You work hard and finally begin earning real money, and before it reaches your hands, a significant portion is already taken (income tax). You accept that because “that’s how it is.” Then you go to spend what’s left on basic things - groceries, transportation, necessities - and there’s another layer taken from you (sales tax). If you ever manage to save enough to think about owning something, you discover that ownership isn’t really ownership at all. You keep paying year after year just to hold on to what you supposedly worked for (property tax). And the more I pay attention, the more frustrated I get. Not in a reckless way but in that unsettling, eye-opening way where you realize the structure around you was never designed for people to truly get ahead. At least not in the way we were told.

Most are told that they need to lose weight before any of their issues can be addressed. This seems to be a near-universal experience, whether in the US or single-payer systems. It takes an average of almost 7 years to get a diagnosis of endometriosis. To the clinicians out there: Are you taught to recognize this bias? Are you aware of this reputation your field has? And are you worried that it pushes people who feel unheard toward alternative medicine or even quackery? Why not just treat a person who says they have endometriosis? I'm genuinely trying to understand the insider's perspective on this.

The concept of personal responsibility is often heralded as a cornerstone of a functioning society. However, its interpretation can vary widely, influencing everything from policy-making to individual behavior. On one hand, a strong emphasis on personal responsibility can empower individuals to take control of their lives, fostering self-discipline and initiative. On the other hand, it can lead to the absolution of systemic issues that contribute to inequality and disadvantage. For instance, when society places the burden of success solely on individuals, it may overlook the structural barriers that impede certain groups. This raises critical questions: How do we balance personal responsibility with the need for collective action? Can a society that prioritizes individual freedoms still ensure equity for all its members? As we navigate these complex dynamics, what role should education and community support play in fostering a more inclusive understanding of personal responsibility? I invite your thoughts on how we can redefine this concept to promote both individual agency and social progress.

Organ donation is the one part of modern medicine that cannot be scaled on demand. You can increase funding, hire more surgeons, expand hospital capacity, and build new technology, but you cannot manufacture human organs whenever you want. The entire system depends on people choosing to donate. Because of that, I believe that if someone is medically capable of being an organ donor after death but chooses not to, they should not be allowed to receive donated human organs themselves. This is not about punishing anyone. It is about fairness and sustainability. A system that relies on voluntary contribution cannot survive if too many people take from it while refusing to give anything back. That is exactly what happens when someone refuses to be a donor yet still expects full access to donor organs. They become free riders. The system works only because other people are willing to donate. Opting out while still expecting to benefit is the definition of unfair.

Organ donation involves no personal sacrifice once you are gone. There is no pain, no medical risk, and nothing required of you while alive. Meanwhile the person waiting for a transplant is running out of time. Human organs are the most limited medical resource on earth. Every available organ literally decides who lives and who dies. If someone refuses to contribute to the pool that saves lives, it does not make sense for them to receive equal access to it. Now, here is what makes this viewpoint even more reasonable. We are entering a point in medicine where there are alternatives to human donor organs. Lab grown organs are becoming more viable each year. Scientists are already creating functional tissues and early stage organs using stem cells and bioprinting. Xenotransplantation from animals is also progressing rapidly. Genetically edited pig organs are already being transplanted experimentally and will eventually become a mainstream option.

These alternatives exist for people who do not want to participate in the human donor system. If someone refuses to be a donor, they should be directed toward these scientific or animal based organs instead of taking a human organ that came from someone who was willing to give. That preserves the fairness of the human donor pool and still provides a path to treatment for the person who opted out. What makes this important is the simple reality that every human donor organ is a once in a lifetime chance for someone. If a donated heart or kidney goes to one person, another person does not get that chance. Giving that organ to someone who refused to donate undermines the entire system because it rewards someone who did not contribute while potentially costing a willing donor their opportunity to live. People often say it is their body and their choice. That is absolutely true. You have every right not to donate. But if you choose not to be part of the system that saves lives, then the system should not be obligated to give you its most limited resource. You still deserve treatment, and modern science will continue to offer more options. But you should not receive the benefit that comes entirely from the generosity of others if you refuse to be part of that generosity yourself.

Obviously, the field of sex work is not an innocent one. There’s plenty of risks that need to be considered. Personally, I do not care about the legality of prostitution - it’s not relevant to me. None of the reasons I found from a google search convinced me, so I decided to come here. To present my point - prostitution should be legal. So long as both parties are fully consenting adults, I don’t see how it’s different from any other business. It’s a monetary exchange for a service - a service which is perfectly legal by itself (again, assuming consent from both parties). I don’t see why it shouldn’t be legal. Religion shouldn’t influence laws. STI concerns could be alleviated through proper use of protection - perhaps use could be mandated. Concerns regarding sexual exploitation are completely understandable, but exploitation and prostitution do not have to go together. Exploitation is a separate issue. Moreover, pornography is legally protected, provided it’s consensual - if pornography is fine, why isn’t prostitution?

I am in my early 30s and when people ask about my plans I usually say something like "I just want a stable job I do not hate, a small place that feels safe, some hobbies and time with people I like." Every time I say that, someone responds with a little speech about how I am "selling myself short" or "wasting my potential". It feels like there is an unspoken rule that you must chase something huge or dramatic or your life does not count. To be clear, I am not against ambition. If someone wants to be a founder, climb a crazy career ladder or travel constantly, that is great. What bothers me is the assumption that a quiet life is automatically a consolation prize. Social media and self help content push the idea that if you are not constantly leveling up you are stagnating. But an ordinary day where you work, cook dinner, read a book and go to bed on time can still be meaningful. It is just not flashy. I think this pressure hurts people. Some friends feel like failures even though they are good parents, kind partners, and solid coworkers, because they do not have a big "story" to tell at parties. Others jump into intense goals they do not really want, burn out, then feel worse. It seems more honest and healthier to let "I want a simple, steady life" be a respected choice.

The letter Y deserves the honor of being included in the pantheon of vowels, not just a participation trophy of 'sometimes,' and I am angry on its behalf. We were all taught that the vowels are "A, E, I, O, U, and sometimes Y." However, it occurred to me recently that the letter Y seems to ALWAYS behave like a vowel. For example, it would make practically no difference to spell the word 'yellow' as 'iellow', 'yuck' as 'eeuck', or "worry" as "worrie". It does the exact same thing as a vowel. (Now, saying "eeuck," out loud, I notice a little glottal stop right when I start the 'ee' sound that isn't there with the y, and IMO this makes the 'ee' seem even more consonant-y than the 'y' in comparison) Now I am aware of the fact that Y is linguistically considered "semivowel" or a "glide" and I must say this seems fishy to me. Mirriam-Webster defines a semi-vowel as: a speech sound (such as \y, \w, or \r) that has the articulation of a vowel but that is shorter in duration and is treated as a consonant in syllabication.

In a recent podcast episode, Michael from Vsauce references an idea called the Bicameral Mind Theory, referencing Julian Jaynes author Brian McVeigh who has written and spoken about it. In summary, he claims that people did not begin to have conscious, "I"-focused experiences until roughly 1000 BCE. He presents two main strains of evidence. First, the records of dreams from before this time all seem to be along the lines of being visited by an angel or other being where they were sleeping, instead of being weird and experiential ("I met a horse but the horse was my mom and we were on the beach"). Secondly, he presents early works such as the Iliad as having characters motivated by the voices and commands of gods instead of internal motivations such as are seen in the Odyssey. How accurate is this description to the historical record vis-a-vis recorded dreams and the motivations of characters in ancient literature? I'm particularly curious also if this is seen at all in the writings of non-European cultures, such as China.

Basically the title. Roman society was deeply stratified along class lines, employing slavery and only offering the privilege of entering politics to those who had never experienced it. The aristocracy justified their role in society through claims of lineage to deities and/or historical figures. And yet despite this strict stratification, successive Roman governments continually invested in highly effective and durable public infrastructure such as public fountains, sewage, and aqueducts that benefitted the elite, the freeborn, freedmen and slaves alike. How were these expertly crafted designs funded as a public project, and not as a privilege exclusive to citizens like the corn dole? In modern Western society, we justify the funding of public infrastructure through principles like egalitarianism and the welfare state, but this funding is constantly threatened by discussions of whether the lowest stratum of society is 'freeloading' off of them. Did similar debates ever arise during the decades-long planning and building processes of Roman public infrastructure?

In this radical rethinking of modernity, Professor Clifton Crais argues that the era between 1750 and the early 1900s – seen by many as the birth of the Anthropocene – should instead be known as the Mortecene: the Age of Killing. Killing brought the world together and tore it apart, as violence and commerce converged to create a new and terrible world order that drove the growth of global capitalism. Profiteering warlords left a trail of devastation across Africa, Asia, and the Americas, committing mass-scale slaughter of humans and animals, and sparking an environmental crisis that remains the most pressing threat facing the world today. Drawing on decades of scholarship and a range of new sources, The Killing Age turns our vision of past and present on its head, illuminating the Mortecene in all its horror: how it has shaped who we are, what we value, what we fear, and the precarious planet we must now confront.

HMS Dreadnought revolutionized warship design with a much simpler layout of both armament and armor, focusing on a few very large caliber guns and getting rid of the multitude of smaller calibers present on previous ship designs. Question is then, why was this general philosophy never implemented on wooden ships of the line? Why not have a single, very well protected gun deck with a dozen total 50+ pounder cannons as opposed to three gun decks with a ton of varied but much smaller and less effective guns? Such a design, would in theory have many advantages such as being able to both out range enemies, while also having more effect on target, and, if displacement was the same, would also make the ships much less top-heavy. It certainly wasn't really a question of being unable to produce cannons of that size as Columbiads were in use, but limited to coastal installations.

I realized today that DPDR is most likely related to a memory-based disruption that can be triggered by various factors. It interferes with thinking, self-perception, and the sense of personality or reality. It is often caused by excessive stress or anxiety, and in many cases there is a main trigger behind it. Triggers can include traumatic experiences, depression, or anything that makes you feel stuck, as if you are in a deep hole with no way out. When that happens, it can feel like you are frozen at one point in time. It is as if you have lost your reference points. You can’t look back, you can’t look forward, and that lack of grounding increases anxiety and intensifies DPDR. At its core, it feels like a loss of reference. The good news is that you can work on this, although it is a gradual process and not something that changes overnight. What can help is looking back and finding your reference points again. These can be memories from times when you felt normal or more connected. Try to actively place yourself back into those moments. Remember what you thought, how you reacted, and what that experience felt like. Do this without comparing it to how you feel now, and try to view the memory neutrally, without a negative emotional charge.

Little Esther, who was just over five feet tall, was pretty tough herself, showing up in Nashville to sing country songs in a way that no one who appeared at the Grand Ole Opry would ever have attempted. Black musicians had been singing hillbilly music for decades, and they had even played on some of the first country records, made in the twenties and thirties. But by the early sixties, Music City was lily-white. Things have changed somewhat today; there are a fair number of Black country singers, such as Mickey Guyton and Kane Brown. But progress hasn’t been easy. Just look at the backlash against Beyoncé’s Cowboy Carter. Phillips entered this fray before any of those modern pioneers was born. And the album that resulted from her Nashville sessions — eventually titled The Country Side of Esther Phillips — is an ignored classic, a collection of country covers that sounds as soulful and sad today as it did six decades ago.

In the fall of 2022, the Amsterdam-based lawyer received a call from a Dutch model who had converted about $1.5 million of his family’s savings into bitcoins and other cryptocurrencies, and sent it to someone posing as an investment adviser — who turned out to be a fraud. The victim had hired a crypto analytics firm to trace the stolen cryptocurrency along the blockchain through various crypto wallet addresses — the equivalent of bank accounts — until the trail stopped at what looked like a promising destination: a wallet address at Huobi Global, a major crypto exchange that said it complied with anti-money laundering rules. Hupkes sent an email to Huobi demanding it freeze the suspicious wallet and reveal the name of its owner. In an email signed “Huobi Regulatory Cooperation,” anonymous company representatives referred the lawyer to authorities in Seychelles, the secrecy jurisdiction in the Indian Ocean where the exchange was registered at the time. Hupkes went to court.

The case for face transplants seemingly made, several teams scrambled to perform their nation’s first. The US saw the first partial face transplant (2008), then the first full one (2011); the first African American recipient (2019); the first face and double hand transplant combined (2020); the first to include an eye (2023). There have been about 50 face transplants to date, and each milestone brought new grants, donations and prestige for the doctors and institutions involved. The patients, meanwhile, continue on living as they can. Some of them, like Isabelle, have suffered greatly. Others, like Joe DiMeo, who received the world’s first double hand and face transplant at NYU Langone in 2020, find new ways to forge a career by selling their stories online. But he and his wife Jessica, a nurse, are constantly trolled, and the spectre of rejection never leaves.

With standard tuning, the bottom five notes on the guitar – E, F, F sharp, G, G sharp – can be played only on the open and first four frets of the sixth string. But once you go above the A at the fifth fret on the sixth string (which is the same pitch as the fifth string played open), we have entered into the world of identical pitches playable in more than one location on the fretboard. The most places you would find any single pitch practically usable on the guitar is in four different positions. For many notes, there are three comfortably possible locations. But when you build chords around those, that means that chords can be voiced or played in multiple different positions as well. Open strings have a different timbre from strings that are stopped, so that’s a factor too. If you’re sight-reading on the piano, the notes you’re reading can be sounded only by playing one specific key on the keyboard. But the guitar is very different. A lone rider often passed through, his horse ribbed and reluctant, the kind that seemed imagined from yellowing parchment and a tourists fatigue. He called himself Juan Christoforo de la Blanco, though none could recall him among the living of the village. They said he was the last descendant of a mad Hidalgo who once charged the windmills of La Mancha, and that he, too, had mistaken them for giants. But this one did not tilt at them, he listened. Keynes predicted in 1930 that by 2030, automation would reduce the need for work to just 15 hours per week. We’re almost there, so what did he get right and wrong? First, most people work fewer hours in less physically taxing jobs than their grandparents did. But we’ve standardized on 40 hour weeks, and much more for people in jobs with a high degree of competition. Within those 40 hours, I am reliably informed, some people struggle to perform even a single hour of meaningful work, but these are not the rule. On the other hand, Keynes was absolutely correct that cumulative capital increase would lead to radically higher GDP and standard of living. If anything, he underestimated how resourceful we could be in finding new things to make and spend money on. This doesn’t surprise me much. Even in Keynes’ time, mechanization of much of labor had increased US GDP by a factor of four or five since the end of the civil war, and probably a factor of 20 since pre-industrial times.

Quantum computers work differently from normal computers because they use the principles of physics. Regular computers use bits that are either 1 or 0, like a switch that can only be on or off. This works fine for everyday tasks but it limits what the computer can do. Quantum computers use qubits, and these qubits can be both 1 and 0 at the same time. This gives the computer the ability to check many possibilities at once instead of doing them one by one. Because of this, quantum computers can solve problems that regular computers would take years to finish. The special way quantum computers work makes them very helpful for science and medicine. For example, scientists often struggle to study how different drug molecules react in the body because there are too many details for a normal computer to process. A quantum computer can handle these details better, helping experts discover new treatments faster. This technology can also help researchers create new materials for batteries, solar panels, and other tools that can improve daily life. In short, quantum computers give scientists a more powerful way to test ideas and find solutions.

When selecting a president, the public attributes importance to experience, leadership, and moral values. Still, one question keeps popping up: is it a must for a president to possess a college degree? At first, it feels like a logical assumption. A degree is generally an indicator of a specific intellectual and disciplined level. However, if we examine the matter more closely, it’s not as straightforward as it appears. Personally, I think a college diploma should not be the criterion for the presidency. A degree does not denote that the person is definitely more enlightened or able to do more. A large number of people go through college, learn things by heart, get their degrees, and then find it hard to exercise good judgment or use common sense. A similar number of great leaders, inventors, and philosophers chose not to complete their college education but still managed to build companies, create jobs, tackle complex problems, and above all, win the hearts of millions. The art of leading is not merely imparted through lectures in a classroom.

There isn’t a lot of time for practice tonight because it’s tenant-meeting night. Once a month, the neighbors sit in our living room and complain while Mom takes notes in shorthand. Most people don’t bother to come. It’s always the old folks, who don’t get asked to go many places and are mad that there isn’t more heat. Sal’s mom, Louisa, works in a nursing home, and she says old people can never get enough heat. After the meetings, during which Mr. Nunzi has usually burned a new hole in our couch with his cigarette, Mom always writes a letter to the landlord and sends a copy to some city agency that’s supposed to care whether we have hot water, if the lobby door locks, and that the elevator keeps getting stuck between floors. But nothing ever changes. Our doorbell is going to start ringing any minute. Mom is running through a few speed rounds with Richard while I make lemonade from frozen concentrate and open the Oreos. Louisa knocks her regular knock and I answer the door with the plate of cookies. She takes an Oreo and sighs. She’s wearing jeans with her white nurse shoes, which she kicks off by the door. She hates these meetings but comes out of loyalty to Mom. And someone has to watch Mr. Nunzi’s cigarette to make sure he doesn’t accidentally set our apartment on fire.

Buck had accepted the rope with quiet dignity. To be sure, it was an unwonted performance: but he had learned to trust in men he knew, and to give them credit for a wisdom that outreached his own. But when the ends of the rope were placed in the stranger’s hands, he growled menacingly. He had merely intimated his displeasure, in his pride believing that to intimate was to command. But to his surprise the rope tightened around his neck, shutting off his breath. In quick rage he sprang at the man, who met him halfway, grappled him close by the throat, and with a deft twist threw him over on his back. Then the rope tightened mercilessly, while Buck struggled in a fury, his tongue lolling out of his mouth and his great chest panting futilely. Never in all his life had he been so vilely treated, and never in all his life had he been so angry. But his strength ebbed, his eyes glazed, and he knew nothing when the train was flagged and the two men threw him into the baggage car.

They were all terribly footsore. No spring or rebound was left in them. Their feet fell heavily on the trail, jarring their bodies and doubling the fatigue of a day’s travel. There was nothing the matter with them except that they were dead tired. It was not the dead-tiredness that comes through brief and excessive effort, from which recovery is a matter of hours; but it was the dead-tiredness that comes through the slow and prolonged strength drainage of months of toil. There was no power of recuperation left, no reserve strength to call upon. It had been all used, the last least bit of it. Every muscle, every fibre, every cell, was tired, dead tired. And there was a reason for it. In less than five months they had travelled twenty-five hundred miles, during the last eighteen hundred of which they had had but five days’ rest. When they arrived at Skaguay they were apparently on their last legs. They could barely keep the traces taut, and on the down grades just managed to keep out of the way of the sled.
